Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Harpocrates wearing festival wreath headdress with two lotus buds, the sun disc and horns, with his right index finger to his mouth. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Red slip. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with dark red-brown core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Gutch dated this piece to between 150BC and 250AD (Hogarth 1899, pl. 12, no.190) and there is a similar headdress on a late 2nd century BC Harpocrates in Dresden (Fischer 1994, no. 647). Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.078) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 92, no. 190, pl. XIII, no. 190)
